40dear little girlloved by every one who looked at herthere was nothing that she would not have given to the childsuited her so well she is ill and weak walk nicely and quietly and do not run off the pathI will take great care,grandmother lived out in the wood, half a league from the villagewas not at all afraid of himThank you kindly, wolf.Cake and wine; yesterday was baking-dayA good quarter of a league farther on in the wood; her house stands under the three large oak-trees, the nut-trees are just below; you surely must know it,What a tender young creature! what a nice plump mouthful—she will be better to eat than the old womannice plump mouthful—she will be better to eat than the old womanSuppose I take grandmother a fresh nosegay; that would please her tooso she ran from the path into the wood to look for flowers. And whenever she had picked one, she fancied that she saw a still prettier one farther on, and ran after it, and so got deeper and deeper into the wood.whenever she had picked one, she fancied that she saw a still prettier one farther on, and ran after it, and so got deeper and deeper into the wood. I am too weak, and cannot get up. Little Red-Cap, however, had been running about picking flowers, and when she had gathered so many that she could carry no more, she remembered her grandmother, and set out on the way to her. Little Red-Cap, however, had been running about picking flowers, and when she had gathered so many that she could carry no more, she remembered her grandmother, and set out on the way to her.I like being with grandmother so muchOh! grandmother, she said, what big ears you have! The better to hear you with, my child, was the reply. But, grandmother, what big eyes you have! she said. The better to see you with, my dear. But, grandmother, what large hands you have! The better to hug you with. Oh! but, grandmother, what a terrible big mouth you have! The better to eat you with!When the wolf had appeased his appetite, he lay down again in the bed, fell asleep and began to snore very loudjust as he was going to fire at him, it occurred to him that the wolf might have devoured the grandmotherRed-Cap, however, quickly fetched great stones with which they filled the wolf’s body As long as I live, I will never by myself leave the path, to run into the wood, when my mother has forbidden me to do so.mother has forbidden me to do so Red-Cap, however, was on her guard, and went straight forward on her waythe grandmother saw what was in his thoughtsI made some sausages yesterdaythe smell of the sausages reached the wolf, and he sniffed and peeped down, and at last stretched out his neck so far that he could no longer keep his footing and began to slip, and slipped down from the roof straight into the great trough, and was drownedRed-Cap went joyously home, and never did anything to harm any oneRed Riding Hood Characteristic Appearances Characteristic Type Number of Mentions
